Squidward! No!

DOUBT: At 6:23 you explain how the Erythropoietin hormone is released. However, it seems to be a little bit contradictory. For what I understand, red blood cells are seen as "transports" of oxygen throughout the body, and lets say the oxygen is the "passengers". You say that when oxygen levels in blood are low, means there is few oxygen molecules there, so, since there is less "passengers", it would be required less "transport", so logic dictates that in this case less red blood cells are needed since there is not that much oxygen to carry around. On the other side, if there was more oxygen in the body, then it would be required more red blood cells to carry all that oxygen. I know this is wrong since professional athletes train in high altitudes to increase their red blood cells level in the blood. It just seems ilogical to me. Can you tell me what am I thinking wrong what am I missing? Thanks.

Hematopoiesis is not the process of forming RBCs, it's the process of blood formation in general. Erythropoiesis is the process on RBC formation specifically.

Circumcision symbolizes the rings of Saturn. This ritual is dedication to Saturn's deity which is Sat(an).
John 8: 44-55 NIV - You belong to your father, the devil. Jewish black hats also symbolize Saturn. Hexogram on the flag of Israel is the storm on the Noth pole of Saturn. The reason why the hexogram is blue on the flag is because they have blue hemocyanin blood while the Aryans have red hemoglobin blood. Also the hemocyanin molecule is of a hexogram structure while hemoglobine molecule is of a cross structure.

great video, but let's not pretend that armstrong's competitive field didn't consist of hundreds of people doing the exact same thing as him.

Some food for thought on Lance:

Yes, he technically cheated. However, the bit that is interesting is how he avoided getting caught in the first place. The way they test for doping is by measuring hematocrit, which if above a threshold (too high of a blood cell concentration), is considered doping. What Lance did is dope but not enough to cross the threshold; he kept just under what was considered "abnormal". Due to this, he wasn't in danger of blood clotting or the like... and he technically was still within normal limits. 

Keeping in mind that his prior treatments for testicular cancer may have nuked his ability to make new blood cells, one could see why he'd have incentive (not to mention competitive edge reasons). 

The fact that he lied sucks, but dang, while he did cheat, at least he was somewhat sane/safe with it (not that one should dope, mind you).
But in all reality, still a little confused here... o2 in Co2 out; where does the carbon come from???

But the point would be to better study physical modifications that could potentially extend lives or increase the quality of lives.
